content.intro:
Consistently listed among the world's top cities in which to live, Vancouver embodies the spirit of the Canadian West Coast. Dynamic, multicultural, green, sophisticated, gourmet, sporty, and easy-going, its qualities are manifold.

Vancouver might be likened a little to California. In summer, the scorching sun radiates off the huge glass towers facing the Pacific Ocean, drawing a perfect skyline. In the background of this tableau, the mountains rise in the distance and yet are easily accessible. Grouse, Cypress, and Seymour mountains, playgrounds for sports or summer hikes, are great for skiing in winter, and one can contemplate their heights from so many points in the city without ever growing tired of the view. The best vantage points are in Stanley Park, Vancouver's emblematic downtown green space on the sea, where colourful totem poles proudly recall British Columbia's First Nations roots.

The Vancouver ‘way of life' has everything we love about the West Coast. It is relaxed, laid-back, and phlegmatic, a life lived in the moment where the body and mind are one. Vancouverites live in a unique and valuable setting, an eco-urban paradise that for several years has continued to rise in the hit parade of best cities in which to live. Dynamic and particularly young, Vancouver attracts the curious and the cosmopolitan from around the world. There are nearly 70 nationalities represented, though the Asian influence is predominant to a very large degree.

Its hip neighbourhoods, dotted with coffee shops and trendy art galleries, are models of ecological commitment. In Vancouver, people live in harmony with nature. Sports are everywhere and it is not unusual to see a surfer and businessman a few metres from one another. Yoga on the beach in Kitsilano, paddling in False Creek, a boat trip along the shores of the Pacific, or canoeing in the North Shore—recreational activities abound. And as in all cities with beaches, there is a holiday feeling throughout the year.

The city is easily discovered by bicycle. Many hotels lend them, allowing you a tremendously exhilarating sense of freedom. The more adventurous will choose a floatplane to experience the richness of the city and its proximity to boreal forests. Just 40 minutes by car outside the city, British Columbia's conifers extend for as far as the eye can see. Its rivers and waterfalls invite you to travel even farther to admire the snowy peaks of Whistler, one of the world's great ski resorts.

map.mapTitle: Our selection of must-see places in and around Vancouver

seoData.seoTitle: Travel Guide Vancouver  - Plan your trip to Vancouver with Air France Travel Guide

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Vancouver

content.title: Vancouver – fly away for a romantic break in Canada

introduction.small: If you are looking for a romantic break, make Vancouver your next destination. This great city has plenty of surprises in store… just perfect for two to enjoy!

paragraphs.text:
Vancouver – Love at first sight

Is it because Vancouver has been the film set for many present-day romantic comedies? Or maybe because of its oceanic climate, conducive to a gentle pace of life? Whatever it is, the fact remains that this city is particularly well-suited for a romantic getaway.

Your love nest is called the Wedgewood Hotel. The foyer, all light wood panelling and stunning floral arrangements, sets the tone: here, charm and elegance reign supreme without sacrificing any comforts. Looking around, there is no doubt that you have come to one of the prestigious Relais & Châteaux hotels. Your room marries warm shades from beige to chocolate with quilted fabrics and curtains inspired by a bygone age. Book a suite on the top floor: you will be treated to a view over Robson Square, one of Vancouver's iconic landmarks.

The frozen body of water below gives you an idea of something romantic you can do together: ice skating under a pretty glass dome in the heart of the city. A few metres away stands the former courthouse, characterised by its neo-classical architecture. Since 1931, it has been home to Vancouver Art Gallery. Inside, you will discover 157 works by Emily Carr, one of the most famous Canadian artists in the world. Her paintings reconstruct local landscapes using original graphics which borrow from the calligraphy and traditional art of the indigenous people of North America. As you gaze at paintings of these vast natural spaces, you are overcome by a feeling of sweet melancholy.

When you get back to your hotel, you pay a visit to the spa, which also offers a couple's massage. Choose the Swedish massage using hot stones for deep tissue relaxation. Afterwards, you make your way to Bacchus, the hotel's restaurant, with its delightfully cosy ambience. The menu offers its own take on European cuisine: the beef tartare with ginger and soya or the chicken blanquette poached in butter and served with garlic potatoes and smoked Tyrolian bacon are a treat for your taste buds.

Wedgewood Hotel & Spa Vancouver
845 Hornby St
Vancouver BC V6Z 1V1
Canada
+1 800 663 0666
https://www.wedgewoodhotel.com

Robson Square Ice Rink
800 Robson St
Vancouver BC V6Z 3B7
Canada
+1 604 646 3554
www.robsonsquare.com/

Vancouver Art Gallery
750 Hornby St
Vancouver BC V6Z 2H7
Canada
+1 604 662 4700
www.vanartgallery.bc.ca/

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

A romantic stroll or two

Next day, you decide to go and hang a small padlock on the Love Locks sculpture in Queen Elizabeth Park, located less than ten minutes from the Wedgewood Hotel by taxi. Unveiled in 2016, it represents a couple embracing. The metal wire structure was designed so that these small symbols of love can easily be attached to it.

You continue your romantic itinerary by taking a cookery class for two at the Dirty Apron Cooking School, famous throughout Vancouver. It is up to you whether you choose the vegetarian menu or the Asian-inspired menu, honouring the city's large Chinese community. Professional chefs will guide you step by step as you cook a starter, a main course and a dessert which you then sit down to eat with your friends for the day around a big light-wood table in a friendly setting.

After your culinary masterclass, head to Stanley Park, a vast green expanse that stretches out into the waters of Burrard Inlet. To discover some or all of its 400 hectares of nature, hire a bike from one of the many rental stations. Cycle out to the rose garden along the park's network of cycle tracks. With some 3,500 red, yellow and orange rose bushes, the place is simply enchanting. Take a stroll under the wooden arbour and breathe in the intoxicating perfume that the climbing flowers give off. Extend your walk a bit further by passing through the more hidden rhododendron garden. To get back to the city centre, you walk along the coast from where you can watch a blazing sunset over English Bay. The meeting of the sky's warm tones and the immense blue of the Pacific Ocean will remain engraved in your memory forever.

Queen Elizabeth Park
4600 Cambie St
Vancouver BC V5Z 2Z1
Canada
+1 604 873 7000
https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/queen-elizabeth-park.aspx

The Dirty Apron Cooking School
540 Beatty St,
Vancouver BC V6B 2L3
Canada
+1 604 879 8588
https://www.dirtyapron.com/

Stanley Park
1950-1970 W Georgia Street
Vancouver BC V6G 1Z4
Canada
+1 604 681 6728
https://www.airfrance.com/FR/en/common/travel-guide/explore-stanley-park-by-bike.htm

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

A day trip to Victoria

Victoria, the charming capital of British Columbia, is well worth a day trip. Sitting at the southern tip of Vancouver Island, you can get there by taking a 90-minute ferry ride across the Strait of Georgia with its string of little islands where it is not uncommon to see seals. Several flights by seaplane also make the connection. If you come by boat, get off at Fisherman's Wharf with pretty, colourful floating homes lining the quayside. As you take a stroll along the waterfront promenade, a queue of people outside an upcycled shipping container catches your eye. You have arrived at Red Fish Blue Fish. The wait is certainly worth it as the brand is renowned for its excellent, sustainable fish and seafood. The fish and chips are superb, but if you are tempted, try their tacos topped with fresh grilled oysters - truly scrumptious!

Behind the port, you will see other districts of the city with their Victorian architecture, a leftover from the city's colonial past. Lose yourself in the picturesque alleys of the historic centre. When you reach Market Square, you will appreciate the tranquillity that emanates from the red-brick buildings. These former saloons are now home to designer boutiques and art galleries. It takes 30 minutes to walk to the city's architectural landmark, Craigdarroch Castle. The castle looks like a Baroque Scottish manor house and just seeing it, perched on the hilltop, fills you with romantic daydreams. Climb its 87 steps and you will be rewarded with stunning views over the city and port.

It is soon time to head back to the port for your return ferry journey. Already feeling a bit nostalgic about the day, you stop off at the glorious tea room at the Fairmont Empress Hotel, all decked out in golds and velvet. You feel a bit like royalty as you sip your tea from a pretty, Chinese porcelain cup, a perfect reproduction of the tea service that Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother, gave to city officials on a visit in 1939. If you want to enjoy this exceptional place, we strongly recommend that you book ahead. Elegance is the order of the day here, so make sure you dress appropriately. As you board the boat back to Vancouver, your heart is full of tender memories.

Red Fish Blue Fish
1006 Wharf St
Victoria BC V8W 1N8
Canada
https://www.redfish-bluefish.com/

Market Square
560 Johnson St
Victoria BC V8W 3C6
Canada
+1 250 386 2441
https://www.marketsquare.ca/

Craigdarroch Castle
1050 Joan Crescent
Victoria BC V8S 3L5
Canada
+1 250 592 5323
https://thecastle.ca/

Fairmont Empress Hotel
721 Government St
Victoria BC V8W 1W5
Canada
+1 250 389 2727
https://www.teaattheempress.com/

content.title: Gringo, a taco-cocktail winning combination

introduction.small: As a hybrid place between a Mexican cantina and a Latino bar, Gringo offers DIY tacos best enjoyed with a beer or a cocktail.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gringo, a taco-cocktail winning combination

paragraphs.text:
In Vancouver's historical Gastown neighbourhood, Gringo gets off the beaten track. In this small yet dynamic restaurant, tacos are given centre stage. Neon lights and pink flamingos adorn the walls for a very 80s decoration. Music also pays tribute to the end of the era with exhilarating disco music. Outside of tacos which you assemble yourself with a mix of beef, chicken, smoked ham or a vegetable option, the menu offers cocktails inspired by Latin American classics. Try – in moderation – the Pink Flamingo, with a tequila base, grapefruit, blonde beer and jelly candies, or the Bourbarita with bourbon, lemon and watermelon. For some heightened originality, order the Thai Bucket, cocktail served in a mud pie party bucket. Affordable festive evening ahead!

Gringo
27 Blood Alley Square
Vancouver, BC V6B 0C4

+1 604 721 0607

www.gringogastown.com

Menu: tacos from 8 CAD, cocktails from 6 CAD

content.title: Head in the clouds, near Vancouver

introduction.small: If you have a green thumb and love the unusual, do not miss a dream night in the heart of the Canadian forest.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Head in the clouds, near Vancouver

paragraphs.text:
From a distance, the cables of the Free Spirit Spheres Hotel are reminiscent of those of a tree-climbing course. Make no mistake, you are not here for a gym session however, but for a night's rest! Whether you choose the ‘Eryn', ‘Melody' or ‘Eve' sphere, you will have a unique experience that will remain etched in your memory. Comfortably seated on the benches of your new cocoon, you will be carried away by the beauty of nature. Through the large windows, take the time to admire the birds perched atop the canopy. Your bathroom—one for each sphere—is located in a charming, cosy and modern maisonette. For a real return to your roots, embark on this unique adventure in the heart of the forest!

Free Spirit Spheres
420 Horne Lake Road
Qualicum Beach, BC V9K 1Z7

+1 250 757 9445

www.freespiritspheres.com

Sphere: from 175 CAD

content.title: Marine adventure on a stand-up paddle

introduction.small: You watch the slender silhouettes glide over the water with disconcerting ease, but never dared to try. Let us fix that: head to Vancouver!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Marine adventure on a stand-up paddle

paragraphs.text:
Polynesian sportsmen travelled on wide planks of wood and, equipped with a paddle, took the waves like modern surfers. Now a fashionable sport, stand up paddleboarding will let you explore the lagoons and archipelagos of the world, standing on a rigid or inflatable board. The discipline is diversified and the material adapts to different uses— excursions, races, fishing and even yoga classes.

Propel yourself with your paddle and let yourself be carried away by the movement of waves in the lakes and harbours of Vancouver, balancing between the fear of falling and the views of sumptuous landscapes. Venture into another dimension of Vancouver: discover False Creek, gaze at Lighthouse Park, and row along the emerald waters of Alpha and Alta Lakes. Attached by a security leash, you will gracefully sail on the beaches of Jericho, Kitsilano or Chesterman in Tofino.

Jericho Beach
Vancouver, BC V6R 1B5

+1 604 873 7000

www.standuppaddlevancouver.com

content.title: Garibaldi, the Gold Rush in Vancouver

introduction.small: A few miles from Vancouver, the 8,786-feet high Mount Garibaldi stands proud and fierce. Rendez-vous at the heart of the eponymous park.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Garibaldi, the Gold Rush in Vancouver

paragraphs.text:
Whereas in the mid-19th century pioneers and gold miners were rushing towards the Fraser River area, the path of today's explorers now forks toward Garibaldi Provincial Park for recreation. Founded in 1927, the park has steep mountains and rolling meadows and is covered with western hemlocks and giant cedars. Intrepid mountaineers and hikers come here to face the purest treasures that nature has graciously offered to man to date, provided he respects nature as in the cultural traditions of the Salish tribe.
Mount Garibaldi, thus named in 1860 by Captain George Henry Richards who led the HMS Plumper exploration vessel, tests the spirits and bodies of sportsmen, while the lake of the same name stretches its sparkling reflections between “The Table”, Atwell Peak and Dalton Dome. Calm and relaxed, follow the hiking trail to reach Panorama Ridge and stop off at the periwinkle waters of Wedgemount Lake.

Garibaldi Provincial Park
1376 Depot Rd E
Brackendale
British Colombia

+1 800 689 9025

www.env.gov.bc.ca/bcparks/garibaldi

content.title: Cultivate your artistic side

introduction.small: Among the many galleries and the Vancouver International Sculpture Biennale, you have endless opportunities to dabble in art during your stay.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cultivate your artistic side

paragraphs.text:
The sweet life of Vancouver and the bohemian spirit that prevails make this city a significant land for the arts. Whether you are a seasoned collector, a connoisseur, or simply a walker, you'll be amazed by the diversity on offer.

Start by visiting the Vancouver Art Gallery, which, in addition to the temporary exhibitions, presents the work of Emily Carr, one of Canada's greatest painters. Not far away, the Bill Reid Gallery celebrates the work of current Aboriginal artists. On the contemporary art side, the foundation of the collector Bob Rennie, housed in the oldest building in Chinatown, is worth a look for works by Rodney Graham, Geoffrey Farmer, Ian Wallace, and Lara Favaretto.

If you do not want to run around the galleries, enjoy the works installed in the open air for the Vancouver International Sculpture Biennale. A must see: A-maze-ing Laughter, 14 bronze men by the Chinese artist Yue Minjun in Morton Park (Davie St & Denman St) and the installation in Charleson Park of Love Your Beans by Cosimo Cavallaro. All sculptures are presented until October, while some remain even beyond the Biennale.

Vancouver Art Gallery
750 Hornby Street
Vancouver, BC V6Z 2H7
Dowtown
+1 604 662 4700
www.vanartgallery.bc.ca

Bill Reid Gallery
639 Hornby Street
Vancouver, BC V6C 2G3
Dowtown
+1 604 682 3455

www.billreidgallery.ca

Rennie Foundation
51 East Pender Street
Vancouver, BC V6A 1S9
Chinatown
+1 604 682 2088

renniecollection.org

Headquarters of the Vancouver Sculpture Biennale
290 West 3rd Ave
Vancouver, BC V5Y 1G1
Mount Pleasant
+1 604 682 1289

www.vancouverbiennale.com

content.title: At the Hermitage, luxury is in the details

introduction.small: This establishment's location in the heart of the city, its elegance, and its devotion to service make it a choice address.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: At the Hermitage, luxury is in the details

paragraphs.text:
Located close to the Orpheum Theatre concert hall in the city centre, only a few blocks from Yaletown and Gastown, the Hermitage has an incomparable strategic position for exploring the city.

The rooms, suites, and apartments are located between the fifth and seventh floors. Elegant rooms, adorned in beige tones, contain furniture with impeccable lines and bathrooms made of marble. The suites also have a kitchenette and a cosy fireplace should you choose not to go out for dinner. Rooms located in the east overlook the pretty interior garden and the outdoor seawater pool.

A business centre and a gym are available to visitors, and bicycles are also free to use for exploring the city on two wheels. If you do not want to pedal, there is a private car with chauffeur to take guests to restaurants or business meetings. What more can you ask?

L'Hermitage Hotel
788 Richards Street
Downtown
Vancouver, BC V6B 3A4

+1 778 327 4100

www.lhermitagevancouver.com

Rooms: from 205 CAD

content.title: Hawksworth: chic and gastronomic

introduction.small: Chef David Hawksworth's restaurant: a star of West Coast cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hawksworth: chic and gastronomic

paragraphs.text:
Trained in the best European kitchens, David Hawksworth returned to Canada to bring a shine to Canadian cuisine. A recognised talent, Hawksworth has ensured his eponymous establishment is regularly ranked among the best restaurants for its cuisine and its wine list.

The menu showcases organic local produce and, like many restaurants in town, features Ocean Wise certified fish, which promotes sustainable fishing. Behind the scenes, the chef uses traditional techniques, but his seasonings have hints of Asia: Saint-Jacques scallops caramelised in vermouth cream, mushrooms, pumpkin and cauliflower, but also roasted duck with passion fruits. It perfectly symbolises Canadian cuisine, which is as multicultural as the country itself.

The restaurant, located in the Rosewood Hotel Georgia designed by Alessandro Munge, is divided into several areas. There is an atmosphere for every occasion, as you would not choose the same room for a romantic dinner or a business lunch. The lounge bar has masculine accents with its leather covered walls; in the Pearl Room, chandeliers and comfortable seats create a boudoir ambiance; the tone of the Art Room is ‘gallery' with an installation by local artist Rodney Graham; the York Room finds inspiration in the 1920s.

Hawksworth Restaurant
801 West Georgia Street
Downtown
Vancouver, BC V6C 1P7

+1 604 673 7000

www.hawksworthrestaurant.com

Menu: from 36 CAD for lunch and 118 CAD for tasting dinner

content.title: Fairmont Pacific Rim: elegant and modern five-star oasis

introduction.small: This luxury hotel, ideally situated on Canada Place and just opposite Stanley Park, will seduce customers attracted by high-tech details and captivating views.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fairmont Pacific Rim: elegant and modern five-star oasis

paragraphs.text:
Set on the green side of Vancouver's inner harbour, the newest member of the Fairmont group is aptly named. Located on Canada Place, the hotel was designed by Canadian architect James K. M. Cheng. This expert builder of glass towers (to whom we also owe Vancouver's Shangri-La) popularised the term ‘Vancouverism' in reference to the architectural style of the city.

With the Pacific Rim, he wanted to make this 45-storey glass tower one of the most beautiful of Vancouver's skyline. Mission accomplished. Its 377 luxurious rooms offer all the comfort, amenities, and luxury expected in this type of establishment. The terrace, on which the pool is installed, offers a true moment of fulfilment at any hour of the day, but it becomes a meeting place at sunset, when breath-taking views of the North Shore Mountains and Stanley Park are on offer.

The Giovane restaurant and Italian wine bar is always full, and the hotel even offers its customers an app to help select their wine or to discover the cellar.

Fairmont Pacific Rim
1038 Canada Place
Vancouver, BC V6C 0B9

+1 866 940 4075

www.fairmont.com/pacific-rim-vancouver

Rooms: from 530 CAD

content.title: The Sylvia Hotel: a legendary and unique establishment

introduction.small: Perfectly located by the ocean and Stanley Park, The Sylvia is a veritable institution.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Sylvia Hotel: a legendary and unique establishment

paragraphs.text:
If you walk along English Bay, you cannot miss its impressive facade, which is completely covered in luxuriant Virginia creeper. Named after the daughter of the original owner, the Sylvia was the city's first luxury hotel, built in 1912.

As soon as you enter the lobby, you leave the world of trendy boutique hotels behind. Far from the conventions of design hotels, it has maintained its original style with its pleasing traditional airs, and you feel like you are being immersed in a retro movie set. In the 77 rooms, there are of course what can be expected from the standards of contemporary comfort (TVs, air conditioning, a minibar, and WiFi). But the common areas teleport the visitor into another time, with the vintage reception desk, the 1930s-style elevator, and the wall-fixed telephone that is still used to call a taxi.

The Sylvia's delicious restaurant and cosy bar are very popular with Vancouverites, who come to listen to live jazz and blues concerts twice a week.

Sylvia Hotel
1154 Gilford Street
English Bay
Vancouver, BC V6G 2P6

+1 604 681 9321

www.sylviahotel.com

Rooms: from 120 CAD

content.title: Quiver with delight at the Abattoir

introduction.small: This fashionable restaurant pays homage to the meatpacking district that was part of Gastown.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Quiver with delight at the Abattoir

paragraphs.text:
Do not be put off by its name, which, if you understand French, sounds rather grisly. Although it is nestled in Vancouver's first jail, the ‘slaughterhouse' incorporates the codes of contemporary decor and is a pleasing marriage between elegance and sobriety. The red brick walls are covered with paintings by local artists, the lamps are industrial, the ceiling is hung with chandeliers, and the cane motif tiles on the floor recall Parisian bistro chairs.

Trained by starred chefs, Lee Cooper puts his talent to fine dining with West Coast and French inspirations such as a terrine of duck foie gras aged in camomile, oysters from the Pacific in garlic butter, veal loin with turnips, black olives, dates and mint; as for dessert, indulge in a strawberry Bavarian cake with honey and white chocolate…
Bread, pasta, and fresh cheeses are homemade, and the wine cellar offers the best of the region.You will appreciate the cocktail bar early or late evening and the dimly lit upstairs dining room, but for a more intimate dinner, choose the sublime atrium, a bright glass courtyard that is calm and quiet.

L'Abattoir
217 Carrall Street
Gastown
Vanvouver BC V6B 2J2

+1 604 568 1701

www.labattoir.ca

Menu: around 31 CAD

content.title: Excursion to North Vancouver's Lynn Canyon Park and Deep Cove

introduction.small: Explore beautiful British Columbia, only 30 minutes from downtown Vancouver.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Excursion to North Vancouver's Lynn Canyon Park and Deep Cove

paragraphs.text:
On the agenda: breathtaking scenery and vast coniferous forests. Less crowded than the Capilano version, the Lynn Canyon Suspension Bridge is just as exciting an attraction and, above all, free.

The more people there are on it the more the bridge moves! After this slightly rough crossing, the forest of Lynn Canyon is ideal for a picnic with the family or a refreshing swim in the clear waters of the river. You can then take the road to Deep Cove. This bay, surrounded by mountains, is an ode to the beauty of the region. Some come by boat and drop anchor to sunbathe. Water-sports enthusiasts will love the Deep Cove Centre, which offers paddleboards, canoeing, and kayaking. The bravest will hike one hour away from the village and climb up Quarry Rock to admire a view worthy of a film set.

If you prefer strolling, visit Gallant Avenue, the only shopping street of the village, which is lined with small flowered houses. For lunch, stop at The Bluhouse Cafe, a small 100% organic coffee shop with nourishing vegetarian, vegan, and gluten-free delicacies.

Lynn Canyon Park
3663 Park Rd
North Vancouver, BC V7J 3G3

+1 604 990 3755

www.lynncanyonecologycentre.ca

content.title: Brunch at Medina Cafe

introduction.small: A must for brunch on weekends.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Brunch at Medina Cafe

paragraphs.text:
If you are looking for a place for a late lunch or a hearty brunch accompanied with organic fruit juice (apple, orange, celery, cucumber, ginger lemon, etc.) and excellent coffee, you will love the Medina Cafe. Located in the area of ​​the monumental public library, in the city centre, this restaurant offers brunch with Mediterranean influences.

The menu features dishes to eat on the go—such as the Harissa Burger, actually a burger with spicy beef served in a pita bread with Hummus and baba ghanoush—but it also serves classic dishes like eggs with wild smoked salmon on ciabatta bread or a very chic healthy yoghurt granola and seasonal fruit.

Do not miss the excellent waffles, best savoured with a coulis of red berries, or ice cream with cardamom for a North African twist. Arm yourself with patience on the weekend, as the Medina Cafe does not take bookings.

Medina Cafe
780 Richards Street
Downtown
Vancouver, BC V6B 3A4

+1 604 879 3114

www.medinacafe.com

Menu: around 20 CAD

content.title: Explore the diversity of Indian cuisine at My Shanti

introduction.small: Discover real Indian cuisine not far from Vancouver.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Explore the diversity of Indian cuisine at My Shanti

paragraphs.text:
My Shanti is located in Surrey, in the suburbs south of Vancouver, but Vikram Vij, who owns a posh downtown address (Vij's), also manages to attract the Vancouver elite to this restaurant, whose facade is delicately covered with mirror shards. Inside, the main dining room displays shimmering tapestries, giving you the impression of entering a Maharaja's palace. The menu is obviously an invitation to travel. The subcontinent has not one but several cuisines, and it is this diversity that the chef honours.

He draws on his travels in each place to summon the best of each state: grilled Delhi eggplant, Bombay sweet and sour shrimp, fish fritters spiced as in Goa, chicken fried with spices (biryani) worthy of the best restaurants in Hyderabad, braised lamb and curry flavoured with cardamom and fenugreek from Kashmir. The senses travel with these dishes, which are well worth the trip to South Surrey.

My Shanti by Vikram Vij
15869 Croydon Dr
Surrey, BC V3S 0G2

+1 604 560 4416

myshanti.com

Menu: around 25 CAD

content.title: The Loden: a contemporary, stylish, and eco-friendly retreat

introduction.small: This sanctuary, located in the heart of the city, embodies Vancouver's modern and welcoming image.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Loden: a contemporary, stylish, and eco-friendly retreat

paragraphs.text:
Postcard visions of the North Shore Mountains and Coal Harbour are available directly from the windows of this elegant tower of glass.

Since 2008, the Loden has been appreciated for its downtown location and for its place as an urban design address only a five-minute bike ride from Stanley Park, in the neighbourhood of Coal Harbour. It offers beautiful panoramic views of the Burrard Inlet, which can be admired from one of its 70 tastefully decorated rooms or one of seven suites. But it also interests those who come for business and who love a nice walk before their first appointment.

Some suites have a small private patio, but the jewel in the crown is the luxurious 150-square-metre penthouse with rooftop access, where the lucky can organise dinners and private functions. Finally, to feel both at home and completely relaxed, every room contains a yoga mat, which you can set up in front of a flat screen TV that broadcasts the favourite yoga channels.

The Loden
1177 Melville Street
Downtown
Vancouver BC, V6E 0A3

+1 877 225 6336

www.theloden.com/

Rooms: from 249 CAD

content.title: Moda Hotel: chic and contemporary

introduction.small: This recently renovated Yaletown hotel is housed in a listed heritage building.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Moda Hotel: chic and contemporary

paragraphs.text:
The century old Moda building has already lived several lives. When it opened in 1908 (it was then called the Dufferin Hotel, named after the British Lord), workers from the nearby railway frequented the establishment, after which it became a very chic club for English gentlemen. Its final incarnation was as a punk and grunge bar.

Now, it is a hotel, ideally located in chic and trendy Yaletown. During the renovation, many historical details were preserved, such as the beautifully restored mosaic floor, the mouldings of the entrance hall, and the brick facade. Artists have painted murals on the exterior walls while the 67 rooms have been redesigned in a contemporary spirit, dominated by beige, charcoal-grey, and vermilion.

As a modern urban hotel, it also features a stylish wine bar called Uva and a restaurant with Italian influences, the Cibo Trattoria.

Moda Hotel
900 Seymour Street
Yaletown
Vancouver, BC V6B 3L9

+1 604 683 4251

www.modahotel.ca

Rooms: from 126 CAD

content.title: Opus: an artsy hotel favoured by the stars

introduction.small: This four-star hotel, housed in a former warehouse in Yaletown, is popular with visiting stars.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Opus: an artsy hotel favoured by the stars

paragraphs.text:
Artists and trendy people like to meet in happening Yaletown. Staying there is a way to soak up Vancouver's 'artsy' environment.

Opus hides its game, because behind an old warehouse facade, colourful retro-pop-style suites bring a touch of fantasy and seduce the ultra-urban. Modern, eclectic, or minimalist, the rooms offer different modes. If you can afford it, treat yourself to the ‘diva' suite where Shakira, Gwen Stefani, and Jennifer Lopez have all slept under the zebra bedspread.

Its restaurant and bar are both assets and good places to see or be seen; the La Pentola, with its Italian menu, and the Opus Bar, where Barry Jackson and his bartender Marty create original cocktails like ‘Jalapeno Smoke', a cocktail developed with cedar smoke. And to get your legs working, bicycles are available for roaming about town as freely as if you were leaving from your own home.

Opus
322 Davie Street
Yaletown
Vancouver, BC V6B 5Z6

+1 866 642 6787

www.vancouver.opushotel.com

Rooms: from 228 CAD

content.title: Bao Bei: reinventing Chinese food

introduction.small: An Asian tapas restaurant with inventive, delicate flavours.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bao Bei: reinventing Chinese food

paragraphs.text:
It is not easy to make a name for yourself on the Asian dining scene in this city where the community of the Far East is so important.

Yet since its opening in 2010, the Bao Bei, which means ‘precious' in Cantonese, holds the upper hand. Behind the neon sign worthy of a Hong Kong or Beijing storefront hides an establishment with North American decor that is very West Coast, combined with retro elements. The chef Joel Watanabe and owner Tannis Ling are reinventing Chinese food.

Thus, the classics of traditional Taiwanese or Shanghai cuisine are revisited with a modern twist: lamb sautéed with onions served in a sesame seed bun, octopus salad with pepper seeds and butternut pumpkin chutney, all served continental style, i.e. in small portions on carefully arranged plates. The presentation of these Chinese neo-tapas is a far cry from the dishes served elsewhere in Chinatown.

Bao Bei Chinese Brasserie
163 Keefer Street
Chinatown
Vancouver, BC V6A 1X3

+1 604 688 0876

bao-bei.ca

Menu: around 30 CAD

content.title: Flirt with excellence at Shangri-La

introduction.small: Whether you consider its location or its service, this hotel is one of the finest five-stars in the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Flirt with excellence at Shangri-La

paragraphs.text:
For its first establishment on Canadian soil, the luxurious Hong Kong hotel group chose a tower that rises to 201 metres, designed by Canadian architect James K. M. Cheng. The gleaming 62-story building also houses apartments, which explains why the 119 luxurious rooms and suites occupy only the first 15 floors.

Refinement engages all the senses in institutions of this category. The stylish rooms are dressed in sober colours, dominated by beige and brown. As for the spacious marble bathrooms, they are the essence of comfort.

To complete the offer, the hotel features an outdoor pool, a Jacuzzi, and a spa. The Xi Shi Lounge, where you can sip fine elixirs, offers floor-to-ceiling windows with a view onto an inner art gallery, and Market restaurant, headed by three-star Michelin chef Jean-Georges Vongerichten, serves exquisite cuisine. Along with a health juice bar and a business centre, need we add that the service is also amazing?

Shangri-La
1128 West Georgia Street
West End
Vancouver, BC V6E 0A8

+1 604 689 1120

www.shangri-la.com/vancouver/shangrila

Rooms: from 291 CAD

content.title: Discover Yuppie Yaletown

introduction.small: Take a stroll in this chic and trendy district, lined with shops, restaurants, and upscale hotels.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover Yuppie Yaletown

paragraphs.text:
In only a few years, this former industrial area bordered by False Creek has completely changed appearance. Its metamorphosis was initiated by the World Expo held in Vancouver in 1986.

As was the case in many cities in North America, the abandoned warehouses of Yaletown have been gentrified, and the brick buildings of Hamilton Street and Mainland Street now house beautiful lofts for well-heeled yuppies. These industrial remains coexist with glass buildings characteristic of Vancouver's skyline, built by a Hong Kong tycoon. The neighbourhood is nice to stroll around in as the streets are lined with posh restaurants, cosy outdoor cafés, and shops.

For shopping, head to Robson Street for casual-chic, where you might buy yourself a Lululemon yoga outfit at attractive prices. For luxury, head to Georgia Street where you will find Louis Vuitton, Gucci, and Giorgio Armani.

www.yaletowninfo.com

content.title: Ask for Luigi: a contemporary trattoria

introduction.small: A must for enjoying homemade pasta.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ask for Luigi: a contemporary trattoria

paragraphs.text:
Are you dreaming of a plate of penne with seafood and saffron or a delicious panna cotta? Look no further, and ask Luigi. This small restaurant (only 34 seats) is located in an unprepossessing part of town, behind Gastown and the railway, but the cuisine of chef J-C Poirier is worth the trip.

If he has managed to beat long-established Italian institutions to the punch after only two years of operation, it is because he serves excellent fresh pasta made on site each evening. Cooking is perfectly al dente and the accompaniments carefully orchestrated: spaghetti with squid ink, braised calamari and guanciale, tagliatelle, rabbit with mushrooms and olives…

Ask for Luigi makes the taste buds sing. The kitchen also produces gluten-free pasta on request and offers excellent antipasti, like the tasty meatballs à la Luigi or beef tongue with Piedmontese sauce with tuna, capers and pickles. A delight.

Ask For Luigi
305 Alexander Street
Vancouver BC, V6A 1C4

+1 604 428 2544

www.askforluigi.com

Menu: around 40 CAD

content.title: Enjoy the beaches

introduction.small: Runners, yogis, walkers, and lovers of relaxation can be found on the city's many beaches.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Enjoy the beaches

paragraphs.text:
Long stretches of sand are common in Vancouver. You would be wrong not to enjoy them. Sitting on a log to watch a volleyball game or to enjoy the sunset is a moment of relaxation that many locals enjoy after their workday.

The beaches follow one upon the other and the atmosphere changes from one to the next. English Bay in the West End is closest to the city centre and without doubt the most popular. It is extended by Sunset beach, bordering the neighbourhood of Davie Village, which offers the best views for watching the sunset on the bay and the boats at anchor.

On Kits Beach, the hippie spirit dominates with yoga enthusiasts practicing their assanas facing the ocean, in a contagious communion. If the water is too chilly for your liking, you can take refuge in the pools, with Kitsilano or the Second Beach pool particularly popular for its 27°C water. Farther west from Kits is Jericho Beach, which is much less crowded and a place to watch fishermen at work. Continuing your trek, you come to Locarno and then Spanish Banks, both of which offer great tidal pools when the tide is out.

content.title: Listen to the song of the whales

introduction.small: The chance to observe orcas and other whales is an appointment not to be missed.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Listen to the song of the whales

paragraphs.text:
Cetaceans are quite fond of Vancouver's waters. It is sometimes possible to see these large mammals swim, jump, or blow right along the coast.

Observing them is particularly suitable between March and October, when they cross the Pacific on their Great Migration. Get a little closer with an organised tour, which takes you offshore to see grey, humpback, and minke whales, as well as porpoises, dolphins, and seabirds. Do not forget your binoculars to observe a back, a tail, a fin… Once an animal is in sight, the boat moves in for a closer view, but within a reasonable distance.

You can also enjoy the coastal landscape and mountains in the background, which are simply fabulous. The tours usually start from downtown Vancouver or the nearby village of Steveston, located at the mouth of the Fraser River in Richmond, as well as from Victoria on Vancouver Island. Most offer a ‘whale sighting guarantee', i.e. if, by some chance, you see nothing on your outing, they offer another free tour.

Prince of Whales
1601 Bayshore Drive
Coal Harbour
Vancouver, BC V6G 2V4

+1 604 633 6413

princeofwhales.com

content.title: Discover vibrant Chinatown

introduction.small: The scent of Asia pervades this Far-East neighbourhood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover vibrant Chinatown

paragraphs.text:
Greater Vancouver houses the largest Asian community in North America, ahead of New York and San Francisco, with 43% of the city's population being of Asian ancestry. Because of such influence, Vancouver has been nicknamed « Hongcouver », winking at Hong Kong.

Vancouver's Chinatown, located between East Pender, Carrall, and Gore streets, offers a complete change of scenery. Herbalists, grocers, restaurants, teahouses, trinket sellers, reflexology massage parlours, and other exotic shops transport you to another place. The large gateway on Pender Street was inaugurated in 2002. Do not miss the bucolic Dr. Sun Yat-sen Classical Chinese Garden. With its kiosk and lake, filled with carp, turtles, and water lilies, it is a perfect reproduction of a 15th-century Ming Dynasty garden and a dream haven for enjoying a fragrant jasmine tea.

Further away to the south, Queen Elizabeth Park is the playground for tai chi enthusiasts. Observe the beauty of the movements and watch some train with swords and sticks. For another Asian atmosphere, the bustling Chinatown Night Market is held on summer weekends on Keefer Street between Main and Columbia.

www.vancouver-chinatown.com

content.title: Plan a barbecue on the beach

introduction.small: There is nothing like a barbecue at sunset for fitting in like a Vancouverite.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Plan a barbecue on the beach

paragraphs.text:
On weekends, Vancouver's beaches are swarmed. Though you only have a few months (June to September) to really enjoy swimming, having a barbecue is very different: as soon as the weather is good, people head to the beach.

Surprising as it may seem, public barbecues are allowed and even encouraged. You will notice that many Vancouverites bring their own equipment to enjoy their grilled evening meal. No need to envy them, as you will find self-service barbecues on Kitsilano Beach, Third Beach, Point Grey, and West Vancouver. To enjoy yourself, all you need bring is charcoal, some wild salmon (should that be your choice), a marinade, and a salad or two.

And you certainly will not be alone: alongside other grill masters, you will come across joggers, volleyball players, walkers, yogis, and revellers who are either making music or listening to it. Needless to say, the beaches, as lively as they are, offer a true moment of Canadian conviviality.

content.title: Granville Island Hotel: in the heart of vibrant Granville Island

introduction.small: The best place if you want to fully enjoy the atmosphere of this bustling neighbourhood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Granville Island Hotel: in the heart of vibrant Granville Island

paragraphs.text:
If you want to stay on Granville Island, you don't have a choice, as this is the only hotel facility in this very touristy area.

The external structure of the building fits perfectly with the environment; its 82 rooms with views of False Creek and its lovely boats will not disappoint. You will be right in the centre of this bustling district where shops, restaurants, and theatres abound, and you do not necessarily have to go far to enjoy the local specialties. The restaurant, Dockside, is renowned for its fish menu and eco-friendly seafood, and the hotel also has its own microbrewery.

The view is simply sublime with the boats moored in False Creek in the foreground, and in the background, the skyline and the mountains of the North Shore. The rooms are just as refined and none are alike, each having its own identity and some sporting nice balconies. For dinner or a drink, choose a place on the outdoor terrace if the weather permits.

Granville Island Hotel
1253 Johnston Street
Granville Island
Vancouver, BC V6H 3R9

+1 604 683 7373

www.granvilleislandhotel.com

Rooms: from 209 CAD

content.title: Immerse yourself in First Nations culture at the Skwachàys Lodge

introduction.small: A hotel, gallery, and artistic residence all in one, this new boutique hotel attracts the curious.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Immerse yourself in First Nations culture at the Skwachàys Lodge

paragraphs.text:
Passing in front of this Victorian building, you may be surprised to see a 12-metre-tall totem pole enthroned on top. Centrally located between Gastown and Chinatown, this boutique hotel offers an immersion into the world of First Nations cultures.

Each of the 18 rooms has been decorated by local artists with salmon, eagles, and other details characteristic of western Canadian forests, all of which are featured on the walls and headboards. Sleeping here is also doing a good deed. The property is fully managed by an association, the Vancouver Native Housing Society, and its profits help support an artistic residency installed on the lower floors of the building. On the ground floor, the store adheres to fair-trade rules while distributing the works of local artists; it also organises regular exhibitions.

In the kitchen, indigenous specialties are featured: bannock (flat bread) with buffalo and barbecue sauce, and rhubarb and local beer awaken your taste buds. If you want to go further, know that you can also be initiated into ritual ceremonies at the top of the building.

Skwachàys Lodge
29/31 West Pender
Gastown
Vancouver, BC V6B 1R3

+1 604 687 3589

www.skwachays.com

Rooms: from 134 CAD

content.title: Chambar: haute cuisine in a casual setting

introduction.small: A modern bistro whose menu mixes classic and fusion cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chambar: haute cuisine in a casual setting

paragraphs.text:
Overseeing the kitchen of this contemporary Crosstown neighbourhood bistro is Nico Schuermans, a Belgian trained in the best restaurants of his country. He has retained the rigour and creativity from the starred restaurants where he learned his trade (Villa Lorraine and Comme Chez Soi), shared in a friendly atmosphere.

Although he has had the opportunity of cooking for personalities like Bill Clinton and mega stars like Mick Jagger, the Chambar is a simple, but elegant canteen, where one can enjoy unpretentious dishes like poutine with Roquefort or fried mussels washed down with Chimay or Chambar Ale, the house beer produced in the Belgian tradition, as well as elaborate dishes such as lamb tagine ​​or venison duo. Very committed, Nico Schuermans also makes it a point to preserve the environment through his sources (Ocean Wise sea products) and his techniques, aiming to be carbon neutral.

Chambar
568 Beatty Street
Crosstown
Vancouver, BC V6B 2L3

+1 604 879 7119

www.chambar.com

Lunch menu: around 28 CAD
Dinner menu: around 40 CAD

content.title: The incredible Granville Island Market

introduction.small: A cultural culinary oasis in the heart of the city, the Granville Island Market is one of the most popular places in Vancouver.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The incredible Granville Island Market

paragraphs.text:
Located under the Granville Bridge and accessible by waterbus, bicycle, bus, or car, the island hosts a very popular market.

The colourful displays present the world's cuisines, but also the best regional products: fresh fruit and vegetables, delicious local berries, pastries, jams, cheeses, seafood, and more. A food-lover's paradise, it is also an opportunity to taste maple syrup and tea from the Granville Island Tea Company, or the beer produced on the island by the Granville Island Brewing Co, the first microbrewery in Canada. Artisans and independent retailers, jewellers, glassblowers, sculptors, and other artists of all kinds have also set up here, and it is likewise the location of the internationally renowned Emily Carr University of Art & Design.

In the evening the island hosts independent theatre companies who regularly programme classical and contemporary plays. Before returning to your hotel, order some fish and chips to take away or any of the delicious dishes made in the food trucks.

Granville Island Market
Under the Granville Bridge

+1 604 666 6655

granvilleisland.com

content.title: Explore Stanley Park by bike

introduction.small: The city's 400-hectare park is as large as the downtown area, and highly appreciated. Hop on a bicycle and take a tour.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Explore Stanley Park by bike

paragraphs.text:
With giant pine trees, paths, kiosks, pools, sculptures, wildlife, and a panoramic view of the skyline of Vancouver, Stanley Park, at the western tip of the peninsula, is the pride of Vancouver. You can take the seawall, a nine-kilometre route encompassing the most beautiful views including Brockton Point and its lighthouse, Prospect Point at the edge of the Lions Gate Bridge (inspired by San Francisco's Golden Gate Bridge) and Siwash Rock, the sacred rock of the Squamish First Nation people. If you make the journey in one go, it only takes an hour, but you'd better book a half-day to take full advantage. At the entrance to the park you can admire the famous colourful totem poles of the First Nations peoples and stop in at the aquarium to see the orcas. Take a break at Third Beach for a dip in the ocean. Finish the ride at English Bay and take in the sunset from one of the cafés overlooking the most beautiful beaches in Vancouver's West End.

Stanley Park
1950-1970 W Georgia Street
Vancouver, BC V6G 1Z4

+1 604 681 6728

vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/stanley-park.aspx

content.title: Kitsilano Beach: symbol of Vancouver's art of living

introduction.small: This bourgeois-bohemian district aligns organic shops, yoga studios, and design shops for babies. It perfectly characterises the sweet life of Vancouver and its green commitment.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kitsilano Beach: symbol of Vancouver's art of living

paragraphs.text:
Senior executives and young families attracted by the relaxed atmosphere of ‘Kits' now occupy the colourful houses of the old hippie neighbourhood of Kitsilano. A Greenpeace stronghold—the organisation was founded here in 1971—the area is a focus for the eco movement.

The inhabitants are totally hippie-organic and all seem to have converted to yoga, to the point that Lululemon yoga outfits and yoga mats, instead of handbags and briefcases, are the uniform of the people. Free classes are held outdoors on the sublime Kitsilano Beach at sunset. More than a hundred students, all ages and all levels practice their sun salutations and assanas in the same movement.

Further on, the 137-metre long salt-water Kitsilano outdoor pool overlooking the ocean is an exceptional spot for swimming, with Stanley Park and the glass buildings that make up the city skyline as a backdrop.

content.title: Enjoy the wonders of Western Canada from the Rocky Mountaineer

introduction.small: This tourist train travels through stunning scenery between Vancouver and Whistler, terminating in either Banff or Jasper.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Enjoy the wonders of Western Canada from the Rocky Mountaineer

paragraphs.text:
Do we need to say it again? The scenery around Vancouver is simply spectacular. The scenic Rocky Mountaineer train trip ‘Rainforest to Goldrush' offers a unique journey through British Columbia's most beautiful views from Vancouver to Whistler.

This luxurious tourist train takes you through the wonders of Western Canada. Leaving Vancouver to Howe Sound via small remote villages, it then leaves the Pacific to journey into the forests where loggers are working with the seasons, passing the sublime Brandywine Falls and the impressive Cheakamus Canyon. Next, in the distance, Mount Garibaldi and its eternal snow standing majestic in the azure sky, before arriving in the charming Whistler resort, which was home to the 2010 Winter Olympics.

You will surely spend time on the outdoor platform between trains, as it is the ideal place to scout grizzly bears… Reserve now because the trip with the Rocky Mountaineer is among the most beautiful train journeys in the world; it's in the same class as the Orient Express and the Trans-Siberian Railway…

+1 877 460 3200

www.rockymountaineer.com

content.title: Catch a game with the Vancouver Canucks

introduction.small: Hockey is a religion for many Canadians, so be sure to catch a game if you are in the city during hockey season.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Catch a game with the Vancouver Canucks

paragraphs.text:
The local hockey team, the Vancouver Canucks, are the pride of the city's inhabitants. ‘Canuck' means Canadian in English slang. Hockey is more than a sport in North America and going to see a hockey game is a most memorable experience.

From October to April, the regular season is in full swing, so do not miss the opportunity to attend a game at Rogers Arena. In addition, you will find many stadiums and a plethora of local sports teams, but if you really want the full experience and share intense emotions, you should definitely book your tickets at BC Place Stadium. This magnificent stadium, with its impressive dome and its retractable roof, hosted the 2010 Olympics and is at the cutting edge of technology.

It has 1,100 flat screens and in the evening, the stadium is illuminated with a thousand lights that radiate throughout the skyline. If the game you planned to attend at either Rogers Arena or BC Place is sold out, take refuge in a pub where you can certainly rub shoulders with fans.

BC Place Stadium
777 Pacific Blvd
Vancouver, BC V6B 4Y8

+1 604 669 2300

Rogers Arena
800 Griffiths Way
Vancouver, BC V6B 6G1

+1 604 899 7400

canucks.nhl.com

content.title: Discover Gastown, the city's birthplace

introduction.small: It is hard to imagine that 150 years ago, dense forests stood in the historic heart of Vancouver.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover Gastown, the city's birthplace

paragraphs.text:
With their old red brick buildings that recall the architecture of the Village in New York, the streets of Gastown, near the port, invite you to linger.

Gassy Jack's statue (John Deighton, so nicknamed because of his love of talking) who gave his name to the neighbourhood, watches over passers-by on Maple Tree Square. Look up to admire the famous Gastown Steam Clock, which chimes every 15 minutes. On Water Street, Gastown's main shopping street, take time to discover the trendy local designers like Nicole Bridger and the sharp concept stores like Neighbour, Roden Gray, and Secret Location, which can only be visited by appointment.

Both coffee shop and ultra-design shop, Secret Location presents luxury brands like Hermes, Aperlaï, Maison Michel, Olympia Le Tan, and David Koma, and is well known to fashionistas. Other streets in the area like Cambie, Carrall, and Colombia are full of art galleries and designer shops. Gastown is as vibrant at night as it is by day and is also renowned for its trendy restaurants and bars.

content.title: Climb to the Sea to Sky Gondola in Squamish country

introduction.small: Leave the city and discover the beauty of First Nation lands.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Climb to the Sea to Sky Gondola in Squamish country

paragraphs.text:
This tour, just an hour's drive from Vancouver, is truly worth the journey, as it affords an immersion closer to the natural environment that is the wealth of British Columbia.

A cable car takes you to 885 metres above sea level in just 8 minutes and oversees Howe Sound, Shannon Falls, lush coastal forest, and the surrounding mountains. Several viewing platforms are installed and many hiking trails are signposted. A shuttle system has been set up from Canada Place in downtown Vancouver if you are not motorised. The ride there is already a fabulous journey as the road to Squamish passes through sublime landscapes. Logging has long been the mainstay of the region, but today many neo-rurals wishing to escape the high cost of the city move to this region while continuing to work in Vancouver. It is easy to understand what attracts them.

But if you want to watch loggers—real loggers—attend the Loggers Sports Festival, an amazing international championship of chainsaws, axe-throwing contests, and tree cutting, which takes place here each summer.

Base Camp
39555 Loggers Ln
Squamish, BC V8B 0H3

+1 855 732 8675

www.seatoskygondola.com

content.title: The Burrard: hotel for travellers

introduction.small: Myths have no price. This ‘Fifties' motel remains true to its original purpose: offering the best quality / price ratio.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Burrard: hotel for travellers

paragraphs.text:
Scenery is guaranteed in this motel, and budget globetrotters will enjoy it all the more when they get the bill. Dive into 50s North America here. This is the era when the hotel was built, and its spirit remains: note the huge neon façade that used to be a highway motel sign.

Add to that a Miami-style patio with palm trees, and Acapulco chairs, and off you go! But that is all the vintage there is. The guest rooms are simple and comfortable, and equipped with espresso machines and Wifi. The hotel also has bicycles available, but make sure you get to them early because they are quickly taken.

This is a perfect hotel for people on a budget. There's no breakfast but all you have to do is walk to the nearest café.

The Burrard
1100 Burrard Street
Vancouver, V6Z 1Y7

+1 604 239 8461

www.theburrard.com

Rooms: from 89 CAD

content.title: Experience the Grouse Mountain zipline

introduction.small: Experience the thrill of North Vancouver's mountains.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Experience the Grouse Mountain zipline

paragraphs.text:
Only 15 minutes from downtown, the mountains of the North Shore offer an easy immersion into nature. The Grouse Mountain Skyride cable car allows you to enjoy panoramic views of breathtaking nature with the Pacific Ocean in the background. For a little extra adrenaline, there is a zipline.

You can fly along at 70 or 80 km per hour, summer and winter, on a course that usually lasts more than two hours! Only three of the five ziplines are open in the event of bad weather. The cable car operates all year, and Grouse Mountain offers a range of landscapes and attractions that vary with the seasons.

These include viewing wildlife and flora so dear to the First Nations peoples, skiing, snowboarding, hiking, snowshoeing, and ice-skating, and there's also the spectacle of a helicopter flight. All of this at the gates of the city…

Grouse Mountain
6400 Nancy Greene Way
North Vancouver, BC V7R 4K9

+1 604 980 9311

www.grousemountain.com

content.title: Vancouver from the sky

introduction.small: Hover over the city in a seaplane for an excursion or a short trip outside the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Vancouver from the sky

paragraphs.text:
The coming and going of seaplanes that take off and land near Canada Place is a captivating spectacle. Admittedly, the view with Stanley Park as a background is sublime.

Different companies operate connections to Victoria and Nanaimo, on nearby Vancouver Island, and destinations like Whistler and other places in the mountains. Do not hesitate to book a trip for your escapades outside the city and come back from the island by the Victoria ferry, or by bus from Whistler. You can also decide to opt for an excursion just to admire the view.

The companies propose different formulas, ranging from a 10-minute flight above Stanley Park and Coal Harbour to two hours for observing the lives of small coastal villages, or the 35-minute tour that takes you above Whistler. An experience not to be missed.

Vancouver Harbour Flight Center
1055 Canada Place
Coal Harbour
Vancouver, BC V6C 3T4

+1 604 647 7570

www.vhfc.ca

content.title: Crossing the Capilano Suspension Bridge

introduction.small: This iconic North Vancouver suspension bridge is a dizzying experience.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Crossing the Capilano Suspension Bridge

paragraphs.text:
This is certainly one of the most popular attractions in the city. Since 1889, millions of feet have trodden this 137-metre-long suspension bridge, which crosses the Capilano River at a height of 70 metres.

The more visitors there are crossing at the same time, the more intense the feelings. Kids love it! Located in North Vancouver, across the Lions Gate Bridge from Stanley Park, the Capilano Suspension Bridge is also surrounded by a large park where you can discover First Nations totem poles and aboriginal culture. These totems, which are read from the bottom up, tell stories of great leaders and wildlife.

Having decrypted these mysterious legends, take the Cliff Walk along the cliff several metres high before passing from tree to tree through a course of 7 bridges. Here, some of the trees are incredibly old—one of them is a 1,300-year-old Douglas Fir!

Capilano Suspension Bridge Park
3735 Capilano Rd
North Vancouver, BC V7R 4J1

+1 604 985 7474

www.capbridge.com

content.title: Discover First Nations culture at the Museum of Anthropology (MOA)

introduction.small: This museum located on the University of British Columbia's Vancouver campus offers an opportunity to learn about the culture of the First Nations.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover First Nations culture at the Museum of Anthropology (MOA)

paragraphs.text:
The Museum of Anthropology is of vital importance to British Columbia where indigenous American culture remains pervasive. Explanations of the culture of the First Nations, the first people to have inhabited this land, are provided.

The Western First Nations were divided into 12 nations speaking no less than 30 languages. It is on land belonging to the Musqueam, a First Nations band that the Anthropology Museum was built. This beautiful modern building, designed by Arthur Erickson, pays tribute to the First Nations tribes, and its architecture is adapted to the constraints of the works. Impressive giant totems are exposed inside and outside the museum, which also offers stunning views of the mountains and the Salish Sea.

In all, 35,000 items from First Nations, Asian, and Pacific cultures are on exhibition. The displays have been fully digitalised, allowing you to learn more by manipulating interactive screens installed in different rooms, the ultimate in high-tech for deciphering these ancient cultures.

Vancouver Museum of Anthropology
6393 NW Marine Dr
Vancouver, BC V6T 1Z2

+1 604 822 5087

moa.ubc.ca

content.title: Visit elegant Victoria, BC's capital on Vancouver Island

introduction.small: Enjoy the delightful English atmosphere of this large Island.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Visit elegant Victoria, BC's capital on Vancouver Island

paragraphs.text:
Located on the southern tip of Vancouver Island, Victoria is easily accessible for a day trip, thanks to the ferry or seaplane. Named in honour of the great Queen Victoria upon the arrival of her Majesty's subjects in the 1840s, there is still a cultivated spirit of Great Britain.

From the imposing Parliament of British Columbia to the City Hall and the sumptuous facade of The Empress Hotel, its architecture reflects the splendour of the British Empire. As you wander between traditional teahouses, the beautifully ornate gardens of Beacon Hill Park, cosy cottages (some of which are also bed and breakfasts) and the invigorating sea, you might think you are in the English countryside.

Do not miss Victoria's Chinatown, the oldest in Canada and the sumptuous Butchart Gardens in Saanich, about a half-hour by bus from downtown. And if you want to whale watch, organise your departure from here as these mammals have a soft spot for the waters around Victoria.

www.tourismvictoria.com

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Vancouver
content.introduction: Located between the Rocky Mountains and the Pacific Ocean, Vancouver has one of the mildest and sunniest climates in Canada, in stark contrast with the cold everywhere east of the Rockies. Its clement temperatures, even in winter, rarely drop below 0 °C / 32 °F.

content.title: Currency and Exchange Rates
content.description: The currency used in Canada is the Canadian Dollar (CAD).
content.validity: The above exchange rate is given for information because is variable.

airports.title: Vancouver International Airport
airports.description:
The Vancouver International airport is located 13 kilometres (8 miles) from downtown.

3 terminals, with the Main Terminal housing the two main terminals (domestic and international)
  • Domestic Terminal
  • International Terminal (Air France)
  • Terminal Transfrontalier

Getting from the airport to Vancouver and back:
  • By car:
    Access via Grant McConachie Way, Arthur Laing Bridge, and Granville St, roughly 25 minutes to reach city centre.
    4 parking lots at the airport. Long-term car park: CAD 4.75 for 30 minutes, CAD 34 for 1 day and CAD 109 per week. Low-cost parking: CAD 4 per hour, CAD 17 per day and CAD 110 per week. Car rental agencies are located a short walk from the main terminal on the first level of the parking garage.
  • Taxi:
    The taxi rank is located opposite the International Arrivals Hall on Level 2 (about CAD 30 for the journey to the city centre, which takes about 25 minutes).
  • Shuttles :
    There are free shuttle buses to hotels located within the airport area.
  • Train: Canada Line takes you to the city centre-in 26 minutes. The station is located between the domestic and international terminals. Tickets cost CAD 9.20.
  • Services: Bars and restaurants, boutiques, free Internet access (Wi-Fi), luggage storage.
  • Website:www.yvr.ca
  • Telephone: +1 604 207 7077

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Vancouver
transportation.description: The city of Vancouver is large (115 sq km) but the transport network is well developed. You can get everywhere by bus and neighbouring cities (Richmond, Burnaby, Surrey) are easily accessible by Skytrain or ferry.

touristInformation.title: Visitor information
touristInformation.description: Once in Vancouver, do not hesitate to connect with tourism professionals to advise you and organise your stay.

information.title: Tourism Vancouver Visitor Centre
information.description:
Offers practical information and useful recommendations (accommodation, restaurants, public transport, festivals, cultural events, etc.).

  • Address: 200 Burrard Street Vancouver, V6C 3L6
  • Telephone:+1 604 682 2222
  • Website: www.tourismvancouver.com

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description:
In order to travel in the best conditions and for your health and safety, we invite you to check all information regarding preventive measures and best practices to be respected, available on the official website of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs: https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/

Your comfort, well-being and health are at the heart of Air France's concerns, and we want to help you prepare for your trip in the best way possible. Find out more about the measures taken to ensure safe travelling on our website: https://www.airfrance.fr/FR/en/common/page_flottante/information/coronavirus.htm#notre-engagement-sanitaire

See your doctor before you travel. It is also recommended to take out insurance covering medical expenses and repatriation before your trip. Vancouver counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

information.title: Vaccinations
information.description: There are no vaccination requirements for visitors to Canada.

For more information, contact your Air France centre for international vaccinations:

  • Address: 38, quai de Jemmapes, 75010 Paris
  • Website: https://www.vaccinations-airfrance.fr/
  • Telephone: +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00
  • To make a vaccination appointment:
    • online (click here)
    • call the centre at +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00

information.title: Food Safety
information.description: There are no food safety risks in Vancouver.

information.title: Water
information.description: Tap water is safe to drink in Vancouver.

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Vancouver
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Vancouver each year. The main ones are listed below:

events.title: January 1: New Year's Day (national)
events.description: The Polar Bear Swim is THE New Year's Day event in Vancouver, organised on the beach of English Bay to bring in the new year.

events.title: January/February : Chinese New Year Festival (local)
events.description:
Vancouver celebrates the Chinese New Year annually.
On the programme: Chinese New Year Parade, New Year's lunch, traditional dance and music, calligraphy workshops, meditation… And also one of the biggest Dragon Boat races in Canada!

events.title: February : Family Day (local)
events.description: ‘Family Day' takes place the 3<sup>rd</sup> Monday of February each year.

events.title: May 24: Victoria Day (national)
events.description: Victoria Day celebrates Queen Victoria. This holiday is also recognised as marking the beginning of summer in Canada.

events.title: July 1: Canada Day (national)
events.description: Canada Day celebrates the union of 3 provinces marking the country's first step towards independence, obtained July 1<sup>st</sup> 1867. Parades, spectacles and fireworks are organised around the country.

events.title: First Monday of September: Labour Day (national)
events.description: Labour Day is celebrated annually on the 1<sup>st</sup> Monday of September. Numerous festivals and activities are held on this occasion around Vancouver.

events.title: Second Monday of October : Canadian Thanksgiving (national)
events.description: Canadian Thanksgiving is a family holiday celebrated to give thanks for the harvest. It generally includes a feast of seasonal foods and a diversity of family-oriented activities.

events.title: November 11: Remembrance Day (national)
events.description: Veterans Day or Remembrance Day celebrates the armistice, which put an end to WWI, but is also an occasion for observance of the sacrifices made in all wars.

events.title: December 25: Christmas (national)
events.description: Christmas is a very important holiday. From the beginning of December through till the New Year, all events turn around Christmas.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for Canada
administrativeProcedures.description:
As a French citizen, you need to obtain an Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA) to travel to Canada. Your passport must also be valid beyond the period of your stay.

If you have dual citizenship, you will need a valid Canadian passport to enter the country.

For more information, visit the website of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs:

http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/conseils-par-pays/canada-quebec-compris/

goodToKnow.title: Good to know

administration.title: Government offices
administration.openingHours: Generally open from Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m.

banks.title: Banks
banks.openingHours: Generally open from Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m.

goodToKnow.daylightSavingTime:
Start of daylight saving time: second Sunday in March

End of daylight saving time: first Sunday in November
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping

In Vancouver and across Canada, tipping is customary because service is not usually included in the bill. Allow 15 to 20% in restaurants and bars, 15% for taxis, a few dollars for porters and attendants... Not tipping would look very bad. Nevertheless, check that the amount payable does not include the service.
